segment.source: Compare the OpenGL ES 2.0 shader pipeline to Direct3D
segment.target: Compare the OpenGL ES 2.0 shader pipeline to Direct3D

segment.source: Conceptually, the Direct3D 11 shader pipeline is very similar to the one in OpenGL ES 2.0.
segment.target: Conceptually, the Direct3D 11 shader pipeline is very similar to the one in OpenGL ES 2.0.

segment.target: Compare the OpenGL ES 2.0 shader pipeline to Direct3D

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Input-Assembler Stage
segment.target: Input-Assembler Stage

segment.source: Vertex-Shader Stage
segment.target: Vertex-Shader Stage

segment.source: Pixel-Shader Stage
segment.target: Pixel-Shader Stage

segment.source: Conceptually, the Direct3D 11 shader pipeline is very similar to the one in OpenGL ES 2.0.
segment.target: Conceptually, the Direct3D 11 shader pipeline is very similar to the one in OpenGL ES 2.0.

segment.source: In terms of API design, however, the major components for creating and managing the shader stages are parts of two primary interfaces, ID3D11Device1 and ID3D11DeviceContext1.
segment.target: In terms of API design, however, the major components for creating and managing the shader stages are parts of two primary interfaces, ID3D11Device1 and ID3D11DeviceContext1.

segment.source: This topic attempts to map common OpenGL ES 2.0 shader pipeline API patterns to the Direct3D 11 equivalents in these interfaces.
segment.target: This topic attempts to map common OpenGL ES 2.0 shader pipeline API patterns to the Direct3D 11 equivalents in these interfaces.

segment.source: Reviewing the Direct3D 11 shader pipeline
segment.target: Reviewing the Direct3D 11 shader pipeline

segment.source: The shader objects are created with methods on the ID3D11Device1 interface, such as ID3D11Device1::CreateVertexShader and ID3D11Device1::CreatePixelShader.
segment.target: The shader objects are created with methods on the ID3D11Device1 interface, such as ID3D11Device1::CreateVertexShader and ID3D11Device1::CreatePixelShader.

segment.source: The Direct3D 11 graphics pipeline is managed by instances of the ID3D11DeviceContext1 interface, and has the following stages:
segment.target: The Direct3D 11 graphics pipeline is managed by instances of the ID3D11DeviceContext1 interface, and has the following stages:

segment.source: Input-Assembler Stage.
segment.target: Input-Assembler Stage.

segment.source: The input-assembler stage supplies data (triangles, lines and points) to the pipeline.
segment.target: The input-assembler stage supplies data (triangles, lines and points) to the pipeline.

segment.source: ID3D11DeviceContext1 methods that support this stage are prefixed with "IA".
segment.target: ID3D11DeviceContext1 methods that support this stage are prefixed with "IA".

segment.source: Vertex-Shader Stage - The vertex-shader stage processes vertices, typically performing operations such as transformations, skinning, and lighting.
segment.target: Vertex-Shader Stage - The vertex-shader stage processes vertices, typically performing operations such as transformations, skinning, and lighting.

segment.source: A vertex shader always takes a single input vertex and produces a single output vertex.
segment.target: A vertex shader always takes a single input vertex and produces a single output vertex.

segment.source: ID3D11DeviceContext1 methods that support this stage are prefixed with "VS".
segment.target: ID3D11DeviceContext1 methods that support this stage are prefixed with "VS".

segment.source: Stream-Output Stage - The stream-output stage streams primitive data from the pipeline to memory on its way to the rasterizer.
segment.target: Stream-Output Stage - The stream-output stage streams primitive data from the pipeline to memory on its way to the rasterizer.

segment.source: Data can be streamed out and/or passed into the rasterizer.
segment.target: Data can be streamed out and/or passed into the rasterizer.

segment.source: Data streamed out to memory can be recirculated back into the pipeline as input data or read-back from the CPU.
segment.target: Data streamed out to memory can be recirculated back into the pipeline as input data or read-back from the CPU.

segment.source: ID3D11DeviceContext1 methods that support this stage are prefixed with "SO".
segment.target: ID3D11DeviceContext1 methods that support this stage are prefixed with "SO".

segment.source: Rasterizer Stage - The rasterizer clips primitives, prepares primitives for the pixel shader, and determines how to invoke pixel shaders.
segment.target: Rasterizer Stage - The rasterizer clips primitives, prepares primitives for the pixel shader, and determines how to invoke pixel shaders.

segment.source: You can disable rasterization by telling the pipeline there is no pixel shader (set the pixel shader stage to NULL with ID3D11DeviceContext::PSSetShader), and disabling depth and stencil testing (set DepthEnable and StencilEnable to FALSE in D3D11\_DEPTH\_STENCIL\_DESC).
segment.target: You can disable rasterization by telling the pipeline there is no pixel shader (set the pixel shader stage to NULL with ID3D11DeviceContext::PSSetShader), and disabling depth and stencil testing (set DepthEnable and StencilEnable to FALSE in D3D11\_DEPTH\_STENCIL\_DESC).

segment.source: While disabled, rasterization-related pipeline counters will not update.
segment.target: While disabled, rasterization-related pipeline counters will not update.

segment.source: Pixel-Shader Stage - The pixel-shader stage receives interpolated data for a primitive and generates per-pixel data such as color.
segment.target: Pixel-Shader Stage - The pixel-shader stage receives interpolated data for a primitive and generates per-pixel data such as color.

segment.source: ID3D11DeviceContext1 methods that support this stage are prefixed with "PS".
segment.target: ID3D11DeviceContext1 methods that support this stage are prefixed with "PS".

segment.source: Output-Merger Stage - The output-merger stage combines various types of output data (pixel shader values, depth and stencil information) with the contents of the render target and depth/stencil buffers to generate the final pipeline result.
segment.target: Output-Merger Stage - The output-merger stage combines various types of output data (pixel shader values, depth and stencil information) with the contents of the render target and depth/stencil buffers to generate the final pipeline result.

segment.source: ID3D11DeviceContext1 methods that support this stage are prefixed with "OM".
segment.target: ID3D11DeviceContext1 methods that support this stage are prefixed with "OM".

segment.source: (There are also stages for geometry shaders, hull shaders, tesselators, and domain shaders, but since they have no analogues in OpenGL ES 2.0, we won't discuss them here.) For a complete list of the methods for these stages, refer to the ID3D11DeviceContext and ID3D11DeviceContext1 reference pages.
segment.target: (There are also stages for geometry shaders, hull shaders, tesselators, and domain shaders, but since they have no analogues in OpenGL ES 2.0, we won't discuss them here.) For a complete list of the methods for these stages, refer to the ID3D11DeviceContext and ID3D11DeviceContext1 reference pages.

segment.source: ID3D11DeviceContext1 extends ID3D11DeviceContext for Direct3D 11.
segment.target: ID3D11DeviceContext1 extends ID3D11DeviceContext for Direct3D 11.

segment.source: Creating a shader
segment.target: Creating a shader

segment.source: In Direct3D, shader resources are not created before compiling and loading them; rather, the resource is created when the HLSLis loaded.
segment.target: In Direct3D, shader resources are not created before compiling and loading them; rather, the resource is created when the HLSLis loaded.

segment.source: Therefore, there is no directly analogous function to glCreateShader, which creates an initialized shader resource of a specific type (such as GL\_VERTEX\_SHADER or GL\_FRAGMENT\_SHADER).
segment.target: Therefore, there is no directly analogous function to glCreateShader, which creates an initialized shader resource of a specific type (such as GL\_VERTEX\_SHADER or GL\_FRAGMENT\_SHADER).

segment.source: Rather, shaders are created after the HLSL is loaded with specific functions like ID3D11Device1::CreateVertexShader and ID3D11Device1::CreatePixelShader, and which take the type and the compiled HLSL as parameters.
segment.target: Rather, shaders are created after the HLSL is loaded with specific functions like ID3D11Device1::CreateVertexShader and ID3D11Device1::CreatePixelShader, and which take the type and the compiled HLSL as parameters.

segment.source: OpenGL ES 2.0
segment.target: OpenGL ES 2.0

segment.source: Direct3D 11
segment.target: Direct3D 11

segment.source: glCreateShader
segment.target: glCreateShader

segment.source: Call ID3D11Device1::CreateVertexShader and ID3D11Device1::CreatePixelShader after successfully loading the compiled shader object, passing them the CSO as a buffer.
segment.target: Call ID3D11Device1::CreateVertexShader and ID3D11Device1::CreatePixelShader after successfully loading the compiled shader object, passing them the CSO as a buffer.

segment.source: Compiling a shader
segment.target: Compiling a shader

segment.source: Direct3D haders must be precompiled as Compiled Shader Object (.cso) files in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and loaded using one of the Windows Runtime file APIs.
segment.target: Direct3D haders must be precompiled as Compiled Shader Object (.cso) files in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and loaded using one of the Windows Runtime file APIs.

segment.source: (Desktop apps can compile the shaders from text files or string at run-time.) The CSO files are built from any .hlsl files that are part of your Microsoft Visual Studio project, and retain the same names, only with a .cso file extension.
segment.target: (Desktop apps can compile the shaders from text files or string at run-time.) The CSO files are built from any .hlsl files that are part of your Microsoft Visual Studio project, and retain the same names, only with a .cso file extension.

segment.source: Ensure that they are included with your package when you ship!
segment.target: Ensure that they are included with your package when you ship!

segment.source: OpenGL ES 2.0
segment.target: OpenGL ES 2.0

segment.source: Direct3D 11
segment.target: Direct3D 11

segment.source: glCompileShader
segment.target: glCompileShader

segment.source: N/A.
segment.target: N/A.

segment.source: Compile the shaders to .cso files in Visual Studio and include them in your package.
segment.target: Compile the shaders to .cso files in Visual Studio and include them in your package.

segment.source: Using glGetShaderiv for compile status
segment.target: Using glGetShaderiv for compile status

segment.source: N/A.
segment.target: N/A.

segment.source: See the compilation output from Visual Studio's FX Compiler (FXC) if there are errors in compilation.
segment.target: See the compilation output from Visual Studio's FX Compiler (FXC) if there are errors in compilation.

segment.source: If compilation is successful, a corresponding CSO file is created.
segment.target: If compilation is successful, a corresponding CSO file is created.

segment.source: Loading a shader
segment.target: Loading a shader

segment.source: As noted in the section on creating a shader, Direct3D 11 creates the shader when the corresponding CSO file is loaded into a buffer and passed to one of the methods in the following table.
segment.target: As noted in the section on creating a shader, Direct3D 11 creates the shader when the corresponding CSO file is loaded into a buffer and passed to one of the methods in the following table.

segment.target: OpenGL ES 2.0

segment.target: ShaderSource

segment.target: Call ID3D11Device1::CreateVertexShader and ID3D11Device1::CreatePixelShader after successfully loading the compiled shader object.

segment.source: Setting up the pipeline
segment.target: Setting up the pipeline

segment.source: OpenGL ES 2.0 has the "shader program" object, which contains multiple shaders for execution.
segment.target: OpenGL ES 2.0 has the "shader program" object, which contains multiple shaders for execution.

segment.source: Individual shaders are attached to the shader program object.
segment.target: Individual shaders are attached to the shader program object.

segment.source: However, in Direct3D 11, you work with the rendering context (ID3D11DeviceContext1) directly and create shaders on it.
segment.target: However, in Direct3D 11, you work with the rendering context (ID3D11DeviceContext1) directly and create shaders on it.

segment.source: Direct3D 11 does not use the shader program object abstraction.
segment.target: Direct3D 11 does not use the shader program object abstraction.

segment.source: Setting a viewport in Direct3D 11 is very similar to how you set a viewport in OpenGL ES 2.0.
segment.target: Setting a viewport in Direct3D 11 is very similar to how you set a viewport in OpenGL ES 2.0.

segment.source: In Direct3D 11, call ID3D11DeviceContext::RSSetViewports with a configured CD3D11\_VIEWPORT.
segment.target: In Direct3D 11, call ID3D11DeviceContext::RSSetViewports with a configured CD3D11\_VIEWPORT.

segment.source: Generating the final results
segment.target: Generating the final results

segment.source: When the pipeline completes, you draw the results of the shader stages into the back buffer.
segment.target: When the pipeline completes, you draw the results of the shader stages into the back buffer.

segment.source: In Direct3D 11, just as it is with Open GL ES 2.0, this involves calling a draw command to output the results as a color map in the back buffer, and thensending that back buffer to the display.
segment.target: In Direct3D 11, just as it is with Open GL ES 2.0, this involves calling a draw command to output the results as a color map in the back buffer, and thensending that back buffer to the display.

segment.target: OpenGL ES 2.0

segment.target: Direct3D 11

segment.target: glDrawElements

segment.target: ID3D11DeviceContext1::Draw, ID3D11DeviceContext1::DrawIndexed (or other Draw\* methods on ID3D11DeviceContext1).

segment.source: Porting GLSL to HLSL
segment.target: Porting GLSL to HLSL

segment.source: GLSL and HLSL are not very different beyond complex type support and syntax some overall syntax.
segment.target: GLSL and HLSL are not very different beyond complex type support and syntax some overall syntax.

segment.source: Many developers find it easiest to port between the two by aliasing common OpenGL ES 2.0 instructions and definitions to their HLSL equivalent.
segment.target: Many developers find it easiest to port between the two by aliasing common OpenGL ES 2.0 instructions and definitions to their HLSL equivalent.

segment.source: Note that Direct3D uses the Shader Model version to express the feature set of the HLSL supported by a graphics interface; OpenGL has a different version specification for HLSL.
segment.target: Note that Direct3D uses the Shader Model version to express the feature set of the HLSL supported by a graphics interface; OpenGL has a different version specification for HLSL.

segment.source: The following table attempts to give you some approximate idea of the shader language feature sets defined for Direct3D 11 and OpenGL ES 2.0 in the terms of the other's version.
segment.target: The following table attempts to give you some approximate idea of the shader language feature sets defined for Direct3D 11 and OpenGL ES 2.0 in the terms of the other's version.

segment.source: Shader language
segment.target: Shader language

segment.source: GLSL feature version
segment.target: GLSL feature version

segment.source: Direct3D Shader Model
segment.target: Direct3D Shader Model

segment.source: Direct3D 11 HLSL
segment.target: Direct3D 11 HLSL

segment.source: SM 5.0
segment.target: SM 5.0

segment.source: GLSL ES for OpenGL ES 2.0
segment.target: GLSL ES for OpenGL ES 2.0

segment.source: Older implementations of GLSL ES for OpenGL ES 2.0 may use 1.10 through 1.30.
segment.target: Older implementations of GLSL ES for OpenGL ES 2.0 may use 1.10 through 1.30.

segment.source: Check your original code with glGetString(GL\_SHADING\_LANGUAGE\_VERSION) or glGetString(SHADING\_LANGUAGE\_VERSION) to determine it.
segment.target: Check your original code with glGetString(GL\_SHADING\_LANGUAGE\_VERSION) or glGetString(SHADING\_LANGUAGE\_VERSION) to determine it.

segment.source: For more details of differences between the two shader languages, as well as common syntax mappings, read the GLSL-to-HLSL reference.
segment.target: For more details of differences between the two shader languages, as well as common syntax mappings, read the GLSL-to-HLSL reference.

segment.source: Porting the OpenGL intrinsics to HLSL semantics
segment.target: Porting the OpenGL intrinsics to HLSL semantics

segment.source: Direct3D 11 HLSL semantics are strings that, like a uniform or attribute name, are used to identify a value passed between the app and a shader program.
segment.target: Direct3D 11 HLSL semantics are strings that, like a uniform or attribute name, are used to identify a value passed between the app and a shader program.

segment.source: While they can be any of a variety of possible strings, the best practice is to use a string like POSITION or COLOR that indicates the usage.
segment.target: While they can be any of a variety of possible strings, the best practice is to use a string like POSITION or COLOR that indicates the usage.

segment.source: You assign these semantics when you are constructing a constant buffer or buffer input layout.
segment.target: You assign these semantics when you are constructing a constant buffer or buffer input layout.

segment.source: You can also append a number between 0 and 7 to the semantic so that you use separate registers for similar values.
segment.target: You can also append a number between 0 and 7 to the semantic so that you use separate registers for similar values.

segment.source: For example: COLOR0, COLOR1, COLOR2...
segment.target: For example: COLOR0, COLOR1, COLOR2...

segment.source: Semantics that are prefixed with "SV\_" are system value semantics that are written to by your shader program; your app itself (running on the CPU) cannot modify them.
segment.target: Semantics that are prefixed with "SV\_" are system value semantics that are written to by your shader program; your app itself (running on the CPU) cannot modify them.

segment.source: Typically, these contain values that are inputs or outputs from another shader stage in the graphics pipeline, or are generated entirely by the GPU.
segment.target: Typically, these contain values that are inputs or outputs from another shader stage in the graphics pipeline, or are generated entirely by the GPU.

segment.source: Additionally, SV\_ semantics have different behaviors when they are used to specify input to or output from a shader stage.
segment.target: Additionally, SV\_ semantics have different behaviors when they are used to specify input to or output from a shader stage.

segment.source: For example, SV\_POSITION (output) contains the vertex data transformed during the vertex shader stage, and SV\_POSITION (input) contains the pixel position values interpolated during rasterization.
segment.target: For example, SV\_POSITION (output) contains the vertex data transformed during the vertex shader stage, and SV\_POSITION (input) contains the pixel position values interpolated during rasterization.

segment.source: Here are a few mappings for common OpenGL ES 2.0 shader instrinsics:
segment.target: Here are a few mappings for common OpenGL ES 2.0 shader instrinsics:

segment.source: OpenGL system value
segment.target: OpenGL system value

segment.source: Use this HLSL Semantic
segment.target: Use this HLSL Semantic

segment.source: gl\_Position
segment.target: gl\_Position

segment.source: POSITION(n) for vertex buffer data.
segment.target: POSITION(n) for vertex buffer data.

segment.source: SV\_POSITION provides a pixel position to the pixel shader and cannot be written by your app.
segment.target: SV\_POSITION provides a pixel position to the pixel shader and cannot be written by your app.

segment.source: gl\_Normal
segment.target: gl\_Normal

segment.source: NORMAL(n) for normal data provided by the vertex buffer.
segment.target: NORMAL(n) for normal data provided by the vertex buffer.

segment.source: gl\_TexCoord\[n\]
segment.target: gl\_TexCoord\[n\]

segment.source: TEXCOORD(n) for texture UV (ST in some OpenGL documentation) coordinate data supplied to a shader.
segment.target: TEXCOORD(n) for texture UV (ST in some OpenGL documentation) coordinate data supplied to a shader.

segment.source: gl\_FragColor
segment.target: gl\_FragColor

segment.source: COLOR(n) for RGBA color data supplied to a shader.
segment.target: COLOR(n) for RGBA color data supplied to a shader.

segment.source: Note that it is treated identically to coordinate data; the semantic simply helps you identify that it is color data.
segment.target: Note that it is treated identically to coordinate data; the semantic simply helps you identify that it is color data.

segment.source: gl\_FragData\[n\]
segment.target: gl\_FragData\[n\]

segment.source: SV\_Target\[n\] for writing from a pixel shader to a target texture or other pixel buffer.
segment.target: SV\_Target\[n\] for writing from a pixel shader to a target texture or other pixel buffer.

segment.source: The method by which you code for semantics is not the same as using intrinsics in OpenGL ES 2.0.
segment.target: The method by which you code for semantics is not the same as using intrinsics in OpenGL ES 2.0.

segment.source: In OpenGL, you can access many of the intrinsics directly without any configuration or declaration; in Direct3D, you must declare a field in a specific constant buffer to use a particular semantic, or you declare it as the return value for a shader's main() method.
segment.target: In OpenGL, you can access many of the intrinsics directly without any configuration or declaration; in Direct3D, you must declare a field in a specific constant buffer to use a particular semantic, or you declare it as the return value for a shader's main() method.

segment.source: Here's an example of a semantic used in a constant buffer definition:
segment.target: Here's an example of a semantic used in a constant buffer definition:

segment.source: This code defines a pair of simple constant buffers
segment.target: This code defines a pair of simple constant buffers

segment.source: And here's an example of a semantic used to define the value returned by a fragment shader:
segment.target: And here's an example of a semantic used to define the value returned by a fragment shader:

segment.source: In this case, SV\_TARGET is the location of the render target that the pixel color (defined as a vector with four float values) is written to when the shader completes execution.
segment.target: In this case, SV\_TARGET is the location of the render target that the pixel color (defined as a vector with four float values) is written to when the shader completes execution.

segment.source: For more details on the use of semantics with Direct3D, read HLSL Semantics.
segment.target: For more details on the use of semantics with Direct3D, read HLSL Semantics.
